chapter.title: Goy
chapter.para: You've probably heard the term goy used in reference to non-Jews.

Colloquially, the term goy is used to refer to a non-Jew. However, students of Torah generally do not care too much for modern colloquialisms in their studies. Colloquialisms could be right or could be wrong. We won't know until we go to the source. Therefore, we will not be referring to this type of goy. Instead, we will be referring to the goy found in Torah. This is the goy stam - the plain goy.

In the Chumash/first five Books of Moses, the term goy seems to have a neutral connotation, where any negativity toward goy would be implied. This may not actually be true, but it seems that way. However, it seems during the time of the Prophets and Writings, goyim started getting a bad wrap for being primarily idol worshippers. This connotation carried over into the Torah sheba'alpeh, where goyim as idolaters were solidified. It is only with other qualifiers that goy changes its idolater status. This is explained in Encyclopedia Talmudit under the goy reference.

The implications of using the vulgar definition of goy are critical and highly negative. It's the cause of baseless hatred between Jew and non-Jew alike. It's imperative to the redemption that we should be constantly refining and purifying our speech.
Zephaniah 3:9
There also is a difference between the usage of goy versus goyim. This is explained in Encyclopedia Talmudit under the goy reference.

sect1.title: Degradation and Repentance of The Families of the World
sect1.para:
The Torah often denotes groups of people as trees and individuals as roots or branches within the tree. These families were all descendents of Noah and were referred to as bnei Noach: the children of Noah. In these families also were people that became the nations: the goyim. Bereishit 10:32
"These are the families of the bnei Noach(sons of Noah), after their generations, in their goyim(nations): and by these were the goyim(nations) divided in the earth after the flood." - Bereishit 10:32 shows a time when all goyim, bnei Noach, and the families of the world were most likely at their purest in being mitzuveh v'oseh/commanded and does, in the seven commandments of bnei Noach. Over time, we will show that goyim not only fell away from doing the seven as bnei Noach, but how the term goyim started to refer not to a nation, but to an idolatrous non-Jew who was not diligent in the seven. Bnei Noach were commanded in the seven commandments of the children of Noah and did these seven commandments. The ikkar term for this is mitzuveh v'oseh: commanded and does(as opposed to lo'mitzuveh v'oseh, not commanded and does). Strong individuals were seen as roots of a tree and their offspring as the offshoots of that root. These individuals were the fathers of their respective families that formed the nations of the world: the goyim. All early Bnei Noach, and their respective goy/nation, kept the seven commandments of Bnei Noach. However, over time, Bnei Noach started to transgress the seven commandments of the Bnei Noach.
Bava Kamma 38 It is here described in Bava Kamma 38 and in Yad, Hilchot Avodah Zarah 1:1 where goyim begin to backslide from the seven and goyim(often wrote as just goy at this point) becomes it's own ikkar term to mean bnei Noach that don't keep the seven and are destructive in the world, while the ikkar term bnei Noach is used to denote people who do keep the seven and make the world hospitable. Instead of being viewed in a positive light, goyim started to backslide into avodah zarah/idolatry(lit. strange worship) and were from then on assumed that their intentions were for avodah zarah and not for the worship of haShem unless explicitly stated otherwise.
Gittin 45, Rabbi Eliezer
Yad, Hilchot Maachalot Assurot 11:8 Instead of worshipping haShem directly, the leaders of the generation of Enosh told everyone to give thanks and praise to the stars and constellations.
Yad, Hilchot Avodah Zarah 1:1 Avraham came out of being an eved avodah kochavim u'mazalot/servant of the service of stars and constellations when haShem told him that there was no mazal/constellation for Yisrael and he would have a child from his own innards, regardless of what his mazal/constellation said.
Shabbat 156a
(The Elucidated)Derech haShem, Principle of the Influence of Stars Only explicitly when the term bnei Noach is used, is it referring to non-Jews that keep the seven. Otherwise, the term goy is used, which implies a person that is not careful in the seven. This is clearly defined and expressed in Rabbinic writings from the Talmud on, which started to use the term goy disparagingly rather than the term bnei Noach to denote someone who does the seven commandments of the Bnei Noach.
R"ITVA on Makkot 9a, definition of a goy and ben Noach
Encyclopedia Talmudit, Volume 5, definition of goy This is similar usage to a min who is a heretic within bnei Yisrael. A min is a ben Yisrael, but he is a heretic, so a new term is created for such a ben Yisrael: a min. From this, Avraham emerged and started to get the tree of humanity back on the right track. Through Avraham, all of the families of the world are blessed. There was an age in history where this tree of civilization was still being developed. These early peoples HaShem allowed The R"AMCHAL states that the collective goyim cannot be transformed while individual goy can and he can be grafted into the trunk of Avraham. Also, it says Avraham is the father of goyim. The Aleinu prayer states that the goyim of the land and the families of the world bow down to vanity a nothingness. Eventually, the goyim will be brought low and Yisrael will be brought high. The goyim will come to Yisrael and attach to Yisrael and start keeping the mitzvot. However, they will be keeping the mitzvot out of selfish reasons initially and not for the sake of Heaven. This mix of goyim will be called the gerim gerurim.
Avodah Zarah 3b
gerar is the Hebrew root meaning "to chew" or "to chew cud" specifically. The war of Gog u'Magog will break out and the gerim gerurim will cast off the mitzvot they took on. There will be a remnant left of the gerim gerurim that will become authentic gerim.
Berakhot 57a

From this moment, haShem will give everyone a pure language and everyone will serve haShem as one and his name will be one.
RADAK on Zephaniah 3:9

sect1.title: Goy and Am: The Difference
sect1.para: The words goy and am are usually both translated as "people" or "nation" and are seemingly interchangeable. However, that doesn't seem to be the case every time. Goy seems to denote something akin to culture and way of life and a common king. Am seems to denote physical groups of people that live and interact with one another, but do not have a common king. Bnei Yisrael is referred to as a holy goy; often translated as holy nation. - הכרמל - מלבים, מאיר ליבוש, 1809-1879

sect1.title: Halachah
sect1.para: Halachah for the goy
There is no non-Jew so lowly as the goy. It can then be logically implied that this not a respected or honored status for non-Jews and something you would want to not be of.

Whenever Halachah mentions the goy without any other qualifiers, it is referring to the idolater.
R"ITVA on Makot 9a
Chatam Sofer on Sanhedrin
Hullin 13a
"The unspecified intentions of a goy is for idol-worship"
סתם מחשבת גוי לעבודה זרה
Rabbi Eliezer, Talmud Bavli, Gittin 45b
"Wherever we write 'goy' without any further qualifiers, we are referring to the worshipper of idols" - Rambam, Mishneh Torah, Ma'achalot Assurot 11:8
Some say that this citation is referring to only the context of wine. It's true that this is referring to the context of wine, but not regarding the goy. It's referring to the usage of the words "forbidden" and "permitted", which in the context of wine are both related to drinking from wine, which can be permitted or forbidden, and/or from benefiting from wine, whether permitted or forbidden. Rambam often writes in incomplete sentences, much like an outline, so Rambam is trying to clarify here. Also, the erroneous definition of goy only within the context of wine would contradict the Chazal/codifiers of Talmud definition of goy. Whenever the term goy is plainly mentioned in halachah without any other qualifiers, it's referring to the idol worshipper. Goy is different than a ben Noach or a ger toshav.
Soloveitchik, Od Yisrael Yoseph Beni Chai, Siyum 7
Sanhedrin 59
Meiri, Bet Habechirah, Avodah Zarah, 53 It has already been stated that these things [laws relating to gentiles] were said concerning periods when there existed nations of idolaters, and they were contaminated in their deeds and tainted in their dispositions . . . but other nations, which are restrained by the ways of religion and which are free from such blemishes of character – on the contrary, they even punish such deeds – are, without doubt, exempt from this prohibition. ]לח[ מאירי, בית הבחירה ע"ז כב, א וכבר התבאר שדברים הללו נאמרו לאותם הזמנים שהיו אותם האומות מעובדי האלילים והיו מזוהמים במעשיהם ומכעורים במדותיהם . . . אבל שאר אומות שהם גדורים בדרכי הדתות ושהם נקיים מכעורים שבמדות הללו ואדרבה שמענישים עליהם אין ספק שאין הדברים הללו מקום להם כלל.
[39] Be’er haGolah to Choshen Mishpat 425:5. The rabbis of the Talmud meant by the term ‘idolaters’ the pagans who lived in their time, who worshipped the stars and the constellations and did not believe in the Exodus from Egypt and in the creation of the world out of nothing. But the nations under whose benevolent shadow we, the Jewish nation, are exiled and are dispersed among them, they do believe in the creation of the world out of nothing and the Exodus from Egypt and in the essentials of faith, and their whole intention is toward the Maker of heaven and earth, as other authorities have said . . . these nations do believe in all of this. ]לט[ באר הגולה, חושן משפט תכה:ה לא אמרו חז"ל דבר זה אלא על העכו"ם שהיו בזמניהם שהיו עודי כוכבים ומזלות ולא היו מאמינים ביציאת מצרים ובחדוש העולם, אבל אלו הגוים אשר אנחנו, ואמה ישראלים, חוסים בצל שלהם ומפוזרים ביניהם, הם מאמינים בחידוש העולם וביציאת מצרים ובעקרי הדת, וכל כוונתם לעושה שמים וארץ, כמ"ש הפוסקים . . . הם מאמינים בכל אלה. Other peoples are definitely goyim as well, but have qualifiers. Bnei Yisrael is a good example; they are referred to as goy kadosh. Kadosh is the qualifier and thus this is not referring to the idol-worshipper. This is a common confusion point where many people will say that "goy" is just a general term. Rambam is explicitly taking the generality out of the equation to let the reader know he is explicitly referring to an idolater. Talmud Bavli, Gittin 45b, Rabbi Eliezer says an unspecified goy is treated like an idol-worshipper.

The beginning of goy as a term for idolaters is mentioned midrash, where goyim are bnei Noach that do not follow the sheva mitzvot bnei Noach closely
Hilchot Avodah Zarah 1 and then for a second time during matan Torah. During this second time in rejection of Torah, the wealth of goyim are given to bnei Yisrael.
Bava Kama 38 .

The acceptance of a goy by the CHIDA's(Azulai) grandson is noted in his journal, where he interrogates a goy and tell him to recite Shema every morning. It turns out, he is not a goy but at least a ben Noach. It appears to me he is the ben Noach of Hilchot Melachim 10:10.

A goy can work the land during a Shemita year.
Hilchot Shemita 8:8
King David accepted the nochri and made him one of his lieutenants.

There are two main types of Torah study: lamud and osek. Lamud is cursory study you do to just memorize and know the thing that you're learning. Osek is when you completely lose yourself in the study and digest what you're learning on a very deep level. In osek type of study, you are completely involved. You are constantly thinking about a thing, concept, idea, verse, etc. A goy cannot osek himself in complete Torah study. A goy can only osek in the sheva mitzvot bnei Noach. He can, however, lamud in any aspects of Torah. A goy can even osek Chassidut.
Plain goy without any further description refers to the idol-worshipper by default. This causes huge problems in texts about the non-Jew in Torah. A lot of those texts cite halachah concerning goy, which causes huge confusion for a reader who might instead be a ben Noach or bat Noach.

It is forbidden for a Jew to teach his eved Torah.
Hilchot Avadim 8:18
However, Rabban Gamliel described his servant Tavi as a Torah scholar.
Sukkah 20b
This seems like a contradiction. In my opinion, this seems to suggest the initiative and kavanah must come from the non-Jew.

A goy cannot involve himself in Torah except for the sheva mitzvot bnei Noach and he cannot keep shabbat. It's assumed if he involves himself in Torah, the goy will use it for avodah zarah.
Sanhedrin 59
He cannot even rest or take time to rest. He may not create holidays for himself.
It's assumed the goy commits idolatry.

listitem.para: "An ox of a Jew which gores an ox of a Canaanite is exempt." They say: whichever way you turn -- if "his neighbor" is meant specifically, an ox of a Canaanite which gores an ox of a Jew should also be exempt; if "his neighbor" is not meant specifically, an ox of a Jew which gores an ox of a Canaanite should also be liable. Rabbi Abahu said: it is written, "He stood and measured the earth; He beheld and drove asunder the nations" -- [God] saw that the Sons of Noah [Gentiles] were not fulfilling the Seven Commandments they accepted upon themselves, and permitted their property to the Jews. Rabbi Jochanan said, it is learnt from here: "He appeared from Mount Paran" -- from Mount Paran [the Giving of the Torah] their property was permitted to the Jews.

blockquote.para: According to what is said in the Gemara, this law applies only to the nations which are not restricted by ways of religions and customs, as the Gemara said of them, "[God] saw that the Sons of Noah [non-Jews] were not fulfilling the Seven Commandments they accepted upon themselves, so He permitted their property to the Jews," as long as they are obliged by these commandments -- therefore, those [non-Jews] who fulfill the Seven Commandments should be treated by us as we are treated by them, and we should not favor ourselves in judgment; now it is unnecessary to specify that this is also the case concerning the nations restricted by ways of religions and customs.

Jews should not receive tzedekah from a goy. This is different than receiving tzedakah from a ben Noach.
S"A, Y"D, H"Tzedakah, 254

sect2.title: Shabbat Goy
sect2.para:
A ben Noach can refrain from Shabbat melakim however he sees fit. This ben Noach should not do Shabbat melakim for the Jew.
Sichos Volume 31, Parshas Mishpatim, Section 5

sect2.title: Goy and A"KUM Equivalence
sect2.para: The noun goy and the acronym a"kum are equivalent in halachah. This is proven multiple places. One way of proof, is when Halachah says a"kum and then quotes Torah where it says goy(Nedarim 9:22).

sect1.title: Responsa
sect1.para: Statement: The goy means all non-Jews

Response: The goy is different than other non-Jews. For example the goy cannot give charity to the bnei Yisrael and have a poor bnei Yisrael accept it. However, a ben Noach who keeps the sheva mitzvot bnei Noach can give charity and it is received. Therefore, goyim and bnei Noach are not the same.
Statement: The goy is a superset of non-Jews
